abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Population Project
            for Pakistan was marginally successful. The project achieved
            some of its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been significant, sustainability is likely
            with donor financial support, and the Bank performed
            satisfactorily while the Borrower did not. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, sustained political
            support is crucial for a population operation to be
            successful in a difficult socio-cultural environment that
            currently exists in Pakistan. Second, projects should be
            firmly grounded in recent sector work completed before
            project preparation work. These analyses help identify the
            issues and problems the sector will face and also enhance
            the quality of dialogue between the borrower and lender.
            Third, a PAC or Project Administration Cell should be
            established to ensure project implementation. Lastly, the
            IDA (International Development Association) staff should be
            continuously knowledgeable about projects on supervision
            missions and provide more intense supervision.
